problem so the kind of thing that you would want to do is you want to you want
to get to the where it is something that you can easily collect data in order to
answer the problem if you have a poorly posed machine learning problem something like how do I use machine learning to
improve my business it's really very difficult to find out what the the data
set is that would enable you to answer that question effectively on the other hand if you got to the point where you
said hey customer churn is a really big problem with my business how do I figure
out which customers are more likely to churn in the next six months that's a much more defined problem and something
you can start collecting data for so then you collect data for it and you
clean the data up in various ways you normalize it you turn it into something
that is actually suitable for machine learning machine learning is pretty exacting about the kinds of data that go
into it because computers are not easily able to identify the difference or the
fact that something like us USA United States are all synonymous so as a result
of that there is some effort that's involved in the in the front to kind of make the data suitable for

variable variables in the categorical and and and so on or vectorization of
words and and so on that you would want to do so that sort of feeds into once
you are able to produce these features and create a set of data that you think
would be suitable for machine learning then you start the training process and the tuning process where you select an
algorithm you figure out the suitable algorithm and then you tune the various
parameters around learning so that the result of that is something that's a good machine learning model that is able
to provide the predictions that you need in order to improve your business and then if the data if the business goals
aren't met you you say well hey can I collect additional data in order to make
it better is there something that I can do in order to improve it so that my
business goals are met or is there a way that I can process the data in a way
such that it's more suitable can I do some what they call feature engineering in order to make it more useful and then
once that's done you actually deploy that model into production whatever production environment that might be and
you use it as part of your production process you monitor it you understand
what the performance is you see is it actually meeting my performance goals in the production environment the same
goals that I had when I when I was doing this offline process against historical
data if it worked the same way then it's actually helping your business and then it's an iterative process so then you
say well I have a new set of data a new set of learnings and maybe I can leverage that new set of learnings in
order to do even better so you end up with this process that that goes that
goes through where you like data you deploy the machine learning model you learn more as the
result of the changed experience and then you do it over again and this cycle
prior to Sage Maker was something on the order of six to 18 months for our
customers our goal with sage maker was to bring it down to two weeks or ideally
even days and this is the area that we really focused on with sage maker where
we said we want to make it very easy to to do the visualization and analysis we
want to make it super easy to do training especially distributed training and because of that we want to have a
stable of algorithms that scales out to as much data as customers you guys want
to use with it so when we thought about that we said well if customers want to
get started with machine learning and they have a large data set which wish
they want to get started but they don't really know where to get started the the
first thing that we need to do is we need to produce a set of these built-in algorithms that is very suitable for
solving these problems in a commercial setting and there's there's a bit of a
bias in and some of the open source projects I won't say it's all of them there's certainly some that are very
commercially focused especially those that are associated with with companies
that are supporting them but there's something of a bias in certain open-source projects where it is biased
towards academic research and as a result of that you see some some things
where the training is super easy but then the the deployment into production
is left as an exercise for the reader if you've seen that sort of thing we wanted
to make sure that we thought about this end-to-end and we thought about it from you have the data in a place that you
can understand it's a data Lake ideally an AWS that you would be able to take do

said is we need to have the set of general purpose built-in algorithms that

we also asked our customers hey what are you guys doing what kind of machine learning are you really doing what are the problems that
you're solving and what are the algorithms that you're using for those problems and we got those responses back
and we said okay if we were to write those from scratch what is the thing that we would do knowing everything that
we know about how to run these things at scale how to run these things highly
reliably how to run these things in large data sets so we came up with a set
of algorithms that we thought we could do really well with and we started out with these general supervised learning
methods starting with extra boost factorization machines linear regression
and and certain auto regressive models and we said okay we can handle the supervised stuff which is essentially a
set of data where a human being or some other process resulted in the knowledge
of what is true so you're predicting something that you can verify afterwards that you know is true flight delay for
instance you know after the fact whether a flight is delayed or not you may not know before but you can predict whether
a flight is is delayed or not and then after the fact you can come back and you can say yes the prediction was right no
the prediction wasn't right and then used that as part of your training set so this is the the first set of
algorithms that we've produced and the second set we said if well in the cases
where you don't have a clear understanding of what the true or not relation ship is there are a general set of
algorithms that people use that are called unsupervised algorithms and in
general they're used for things like grouping grouping related objects together or they're used for what they
call dimensionality reduction so they're trying to pull out the key aspects of of
those those collection of objects so that you can do various other types of
machine learning on top of them so we said okay let's start out with with clustering and and principal component
analysis two of which are very common methods for for use in in unsupervised
applications and then we said well we've got those but we also want to make sure
that we have specific algorithms that are useful in certain verticals so we
said we'll do image classification I would add object detection to this list

focused ones and then we have a set around primarily around language focused
so if you have big sets of text like reviews or call center transcripts or

we have a set of algorithms that are based around that so the topic modeling
sequence the sequence is something that's useful for for summarization
blazing text is a converts words to vectors so this set of algorithms we
thought is is like a baseline set where if you're starting out with your machine

you can start with these machine learning processes the other thing that
we did here was we said we have to design them for huge data sets so we
looked at existing implementations of these algorithms and I'll present a bit
of data later but essentially you see that some of these algorithms don't even work with fairly realistic data sets
that you have today like terabyte scale data sets I mean terabytes is a lot of data but at

not really an unrealistic amount of data and we saw that some customers and in

will work with these data sets traditionally the way the way that algorithms work is you copy the data set
to each instance so then if you have ten training instances you now have 10x the
amount of storage that you did before and if you were paying for a terabyte you know you're now paying for eleven
because you went from the original terabyte that was stored you copied it to all the instances now you've got ten
one terabyte on each you've got 11 times the storage cost and it multiplies super
rapidly so we said ok that doesn't work that's it's just not what we want our customers to do let's try and figure out
how to stream these datasets so the first thing we did was let's have streaming datasets and support all of
these algorithms make sure that they support these streaming datasets the second thing we did was we said well
if it's a really big data set you don't want to keep going back in the data set and start training and then go back and
then forward and back and that just ends up being really slow because in general a random access to today des is much
slower than sequential access so we said ok we'd have to do single pass not just
streaming but it has to be single pass the third thing we said was if you want to terabytes here a terabyte scale try
you can't fail in the middle because if you fail in the middle you fail 3/4 of the way through or 90% of the way
through and then you have to go back just because something crashed that's just not the way to train a terabyte
scale dataset so we said the third thing we have to do is we have to have great reliability on these large data sets so
we started out with this premise and then we started looking at the characteristics of how these algorithms
actually work so usually there's this relationship between cost and time and
you say well if you want to if you want to train quickly if you want to train
quickly then you end up paying more compared to a single machine so because
there's some cost involved of distributing the data around and and and having multiple machines and there's
some communication cost between these these instances and we said well can we
can we actually do something better so for starters we said okay well streaming
will help because the way we would address it if we were streaming is we'd
have this this relatively constant memory and we'd bring it down so that
we'd see roughly linear growth in time time and cost with respect to data size
so that's not too bad it's not as bad as as what we saw before the fact that we

and traditionally the way you do it you copy all the data to all of these the
these machines they all have a copy of the data they all have their individual state and then you have some sort of
reduce step at the end to to consolidate
all of the learning from all of these instead what we what we decided it was
we need this shared state idea so they they each have a piece of the data
they'd calculate their their local state and then they'd share the state using a parameter server type
of infrastructure or there's there's a couple of other models that have come out since then that allow these
instances to share knowledge even during the training process so when we did
those two steps what we ended up seeing was we actually ended up seeing the
